intro: Lycianthes peduncularis, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a herbaceous annual plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other nightshades like tomatoes and potatoes. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring simple, alternate leaves that are ovate to lanceolate in shape. Its flowers are yellow with five petals, and it produces small, round berries that are yellow when ripe. The plant is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields, and it has some medicinal uses in traditional practices.
